title: Commercial Uses of Species Found in ABNJ
text:
Welcome

Welcome to our species list. We have analysed records relating to thousands of species found in Areas Beyond National Jurisdiction (ABNJ) to identify any commercial uses. The list you see here shows those species for which commercial uses have been found. You can scroll through the sidebar to learn more about the commercial uses of each species.
These summaries were generated by an AI model and may contain errors. Manual review is recommended for important information.

title: 1  Abalistes stellatus
text:
1.3 Summary:
Abalistes stellatus, commonly known as the Starry triggerfish, is a species of fish belonging to the family Balistidae. It was first described by Anonymous in 1798. This species is found in the Indo-West Pacific, including the Red Sea, East Africa, northern Australia, and Fiji, with a range extending northward to southern Japan.
The Starry triggerfish has a distinct appearance with a compressed body and a large head. It is characterized by its unique coloration, which consists of a dark blue or black background with numerous small white spots, giving it a “starry” appearance. It has three dorsal spines and 25-27 dorsal soft rays.
These fish inhabit coastal areas, often found over muddy and sandy bottoms, as well as around reefs, sponges, and algae. They can be found at depths ranging from 7 to 350 meters. Juveniles are commonly found in sheltered coastal bays and estuaries with outcrops of rubble or debris on open substrates.
Starry triggerfish feed on benthic animals and are known to be opportunistic predators. They are oviparous, with distinct pairing during breeding. The market for Starry triggerfish includes both commercial fisheries and the aquarium trade. They are caught for food and are also popular in the aquarium hobby due to their unique appearance.
In terms of commercial use, Starry triggerfish are commercially fished for food and are marketed fresh and dried-salted. They are also sought after in the aquarium trade due to their striking coloration and interesting behavior.
Overall, Abalistes stellatus, or the Starry triggerfish, is a commercially important fish species that is both harvested for food and sought after in the aquarium trade.

title: 5  Acanthephyra pelagica
text:
5.3 Summary:
Acanthephyra pelagica, commonly known as the pelagic red shrimp, is a species of deep-sea shrimp belonging to the family Oplophoridae. It is widely distributed in the world’s oceans, inhabiting deep waters from the surface down to depths of around 2000 meters.
The pelagic red shrimp is characterized by its bright red coloration and elongated body shape. It has long, slender pereiopods (legs) and a pair of large, well-developed eyes. This species is known for its ability to produce bioluminescent light, which it uses for communication and predator avoidance in the dark depths of the ocean.
Pelagic red shrimp are carnivorous and feed on a variety of small organisms, including zooplankton and other small crustaceans. They are an important part of the deep-sea food web, serving as prey for larger predators such as fish and marine mammals.
In terms of commercial importance, Acanthephyra pelagica is occasionally caught as bycatch in deep-sea fisheries. However, it is not a targeted species and is generally not commercially exploited on a large scale. The pelagic red shrimp is also sometimes used as bait in recreational fishing.

title: 7  Acanthocybium solandri
text:
7.3 Summary:
Acanthocybium solandri, commonly known as Wahoo, is a species of fish belonging to the family Scombridae. It is found worldwide in tropical and subtropical seas. Wahoo is best known to sports fishermen for its speed and high-quality flesh, making it a prized game fish. In Hawaii, it is known as “ono.”
Wahoo has a streamlined body with a beak-like snout filled with tiny serrated teeth. It has several small fins along its dorsal and ventral ridges, trailing off with a series of vertical bars on its sides. The back of the fish is iridescent bluish-green, while the sides are silvery.
This species is pelagic and oceanic, frequently found in loose aggregations rather than compact schools. Wahoo feeds on fishes and squids and is an important sport fish in some areas. It is marketed fresh, salted, or spice-cured, and its flesh is of very good quality.
While Wahoo is commercially fished and valued as a game fish, there is no specific information available regarding other commercial products derived from Acanthocybium solandri.

They are epipelagic, estuarine, zooplanktonic organisms that play important roles in marine ecosystems. Acartia copepods are predators on zooplankton and juvenile fish and serve as a food source for higher trophic levels. They are typically found in coastal waters, estuaries, and other marine environments.
While Acartia copepods are ecologically significant, there is limited information available on specific commercial products derived from Acartia or their potential uses. However, Acartia tonsa, a species within the Acartia genus, has been used in commercial fish hatcheries as a food source for larval fish and crustaceans. It has also been utilized in mass aquaculture tanks and for controlling harmful algal blooms.

Achelia spicata is a carnivorous species that feeds on small invertebrates. They are gonochoric and sexually dimorphic, with males usually suspending themselves beneath the female during copulation. Sea spiders play a role in marine ecosystems as predators and scavengers.

title: 15  Acrocirridae
text:
15.3 Summary:
Acrocirridae is a family of polychaete worms belonging to the subclass Sedentaria and the order Terebellida. These worms are primarily detritivores, catching falling particles with numerous long prostomial tentacles. The family Acrocirridae consists of at least eight known genera and 21 described species and subspecies.
Most acrocirrids are benthic animals, dwelling on the seabed. However, two genera, Swima and Teuthidodrilus, have evolved or adapted to a pelagic (free-swimming) habitat. These worms are primarily found in the Indian Ocean, Atlantic Ocean, and Antarctic Atlantic.
Limited information is available on the specific biology, ecology, and commercial utilization of Acrocirridae. Further research is needed to explore their life cycle, feeding habits, and potential applications in various industries.

title: 20  Aequorea
text:
20.3 Summary:
Aequorea is a genus of bioluminescent jellyfish belonging to the family Aequoreidae. The most well-known species in this genus is Aequorea victoria, commonly known as the crystal jellyfish. Aequorea jellyfish are found in the cold waters of the Pacific Ocean, particularly along the west coast of North America.
Aequorea jellyfish have a transparent bell-shaped body with long, delicate tentacles. They are known for their bioluminescent properties, which are attributed to a protein called green fluorescent protein (GFP). GFP emits a green light when exposed to certain wavelengths of light. This unique characteristic has made Aequorea jellyfish a valuable tool in scientific research, particularly in the field of molecular biology.
The discovery and isolation of GFP from Aequorea jellyfish have revolutionized the field of biotechnology. GFP is widely used as a fluorescent marker in various biological studies, allowing scientists to track and visualize specific molecules and processes within cells and organisms. It has applications in fields such as genetics, cell biology, neurobiology, and medicine.
In addition to GFP, Aequorea jellyfish also produce other bioluminescent proteins, such as aequorin, which emits blue light. Aequorin has been used in research to study calcium ion concentrations in cells and organisms.
While Aequorea jellyfish have significant scientific and biotechnological importance, they are not commercially targeted or utilized for specific commercial products. However, their bioluminescent proteins, particularly GFP, have led to the development of various biotechnological tools and applications.

Aidanosagitta neglecta is a species of arrow worm belonging to the family Sagittidae. It was first described by Aida in 1897. Arrow worms are small, carnivorous marine organisms that rely on dorso-ventral undulatory swimming to move around. They have a vermiform body shape and exhibit bilateral symmetry.
Aidanosagitta neglecta is found in the Indo-Pacific region, specifically between 30°S to 30°N. It is an epipelagic species, inhabiting the upper layers of the water column. These organisms are known to be planktonic, living in the fluid medium of the ocean but unable to maintain their position independently of water movement.
As carnivores, Aidanosagitta neglecta primarily feeds on animal tissue. They are opportunistic predators that detect prey by sensing their movement, such as the beating motions of larvaceans. They may also feed on other chaetognath species. These organisms exhibit diel vertical migratory behavior, moving vertically in the water column during different times of the day.

title: 32  Alepisaurus ferox

32.3 Summary:
Alepisaurus ferox, commonly known as the lancetfish, is a species of deep-sea fish belonging to the family Alepisauridae. It is found in various oceanic regions, including the Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific Oceans. The lancetfish is known for its unique appearance, with a long, slender body and a large mouth filled with sharp teeth. It has a sail-like dorsal fin and a long, whip-like tail.
Lancetfish are predatory fish that feed on a variety of prey, including smaller fish, squid, and crustaceans. They are known for their aggressive hunting behavior and are capable of capturing prey larger than themselves. Lancetfish are capable of vertical migration, moving between different depths of the ocean.
While lancetfish are not typically targeted for commercial fishing, they are occasionally caught as bycatch in deep-sea fisheries. The flesh of the lancetfish is not commonly consumed by humans due to its strong, oily taste. However, some reports suggest that the liver of the lancetfish may contain high levels of vitamin A and omega-3 fatty acids, which could have potential commercial value.
Limited information is available regarding the commercial value of lancetfish and its derived products. Further research may be needed to explore any potential commercial uses or economic significance of this fish species.

title: 37  Alopias superciliosus
text:
37.3 Summary:
Alopias superciliosus, commonly known as the bigeye thresher shark, is a species of shark belonging to the family Alopiidae. It is one of the three recognized species of thresher sharks. The bigeye thresher shark is characterized by its long, slender body, large eyes, and a distinctive long upper caudal fin lobe that can be as long as the shark’s body.
Bigeye thresher sharks are found in tropical and temperate waters of the Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific Oceans. They are primarily pelagic, inhabiting open ocean areas and continental shelves. These sharks are known to undertake long-distance migrations, often diving to great depths.
In terms of ecology, bigeye thresher sharks are apex predators in their marine ecosystems. They primarily feed on small schooling fish, squid, and occasionally pelagic crustaceans. Their unique caudal fin is believed to be used as a hunting tool, stunning prey with powerful strikes.
While bigeye thresher sharks are commercially fished for their meat, fins, and liver oil, there is limited information available about specific commercial products derived from Alopias superciliosus. The shark’s large size and impressive appearance make it a target for sport fishing, but it is also caught as bycatch in various fisheries. Conservation efforts are in place to manage and protect thresher shark populations due to concerns about overfishing and population decline.

Shark meat: Bigeye thresher sharks are commercially fished for their meat, which is consumed in some regions. The meat is typically sold fresh, frozen, or processed into various seafood products.

Shark liver oil: The liver of bigeye thresher sharks is rich in oil, which is extracted and used in various industries, including cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and dietary supplements.

Please note that the commercial exploitation of sharks, including bigeye thresher sharks, raises concerns about sustainability and the impact on shark populations. Conservation measures and regulations are in place to ensure responsible fishing practices.

38.3 Summary:
Alopias vulpinus, commonly known as the thresher shark, is a species of large, pelagic shark found in both tropical and temperate oceans worldwide. Thresher sharks are known for their distinctive long, whip-like tails, which can be as long as their body length. They have a streamlined body shape, large eyes, and a mouth filled with sharp teeth.
Thresher sharks are primarily solitary and are often found in deep offshore waters, although they can also be found near the coast. They are highly migratory, traveling long distances in search of food and suitable breeding grounds. Thresher sharks feed on a variety of prey, including small fish, squid, and pelagic schooling species.
The thresher shark is not targeted for commercial fishing in most regions, but it is occasionally caught as bycatch in various fisheries. Its long tail is highly valued for its use in the shark fin trade. Thresher sharks are also sought after by recreational anglers for their size and fighting ability.
In terms of commercial products, thresher sharks are primarily targeted for their meat, fins, and liver oil. The meat is consumed in some regions, while the fins are used in the production of shark fin soup, a delicacy in certain cultures. The liver oil is extracted and used in various products, including cosmetics, dietary supplements, and traditional medicine.
However, it is important to note that thresher sharks are facing population declines and are listed as vulnerable or endangered by several conservation organizations. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has classified Alopias vulpinus as vulnerable globally. Conservation efforts are being implemented to protect thresher sharks and regulate their fishing.

Meat: Thresher shark meat is consumed in some regions, primarily in Asia. It is used in various dishes and can be found in local markets.

The unicorn leatherjacket has a highly compressed and elongated oval-shaped body. It has a long pointed snout and a small mouth that opens above the center. The upper snout profile of adults is convex, while the lower profile is concave. The body of the unicorn leatherjacket is usually brown to grey with brown spots on the upper sides and a dark caudal fin. It has a highly compressed body structure.
Unicorn leatherjackets are typically found near reefs and occasionally in shallow waters near steep drop-offs. They are often observed either singly or in pairs, but can also form small groups. Juveniles of this species are pelagic, meaning they live in the open ocean.
In terms of commercial value, the unicorn leatherjacket is sometimes harvested for consumption. It is one of the three main types of leatherfish eaten in Japan, along with black scraper and thread-sail filefish. However, there is limited information available regarding specific commercial products derived from the unicorn leatherjacket.

title: 52  Anarhichas denticulatus

52.3 Summary:
Anarhichas denticulatus, commonly known as the wolfish, is a species of fish belonging to the family Anarhichadidae. It is found in the North Atlantic Ocean, particularly in the waters of the Arctic and sub-Arctic regions. The wolfish is a demersal species, meaning it inhabits the ocean floor.
The wolfish has a distinctive appearance with a long, slender body and a large head. It can grow up to 1.5 meters in length and weigh up to 20 kilograms. The coloration of the wolfish varies, but it is typically dark brown or black with lighter spots or blotches. It has sharp teeth and a strong jaw, which it uses to feed on a variety of prey, including fish, crustaceans, and mollusks.
In terms of commercial products, the wolfish is commercially harvested for its meat, which is considered a delicacy in some regions. The flesh of the wolfish is white, firm, and flavorful, making it suitable for various culinary preparations. It is often used in dishes such as fish stews, soups, and fillets. The skin of the wolfish is also used in the production of leather goods.
Due to its popularity as a food fish, the wolfish is subject to commercial fishing regulations and management measures to ensure sustainable harvesting. These regulations aim to maintain healthy populations of the species and prevent overfishing.

Anarhichas lupus, commonly known as the Atlantic wolffish, is a species of marine fish belonging to the family Anarhichadidae. It is found in the North Atlantic Ocean, ranging from Greenland and Iceland to the coasts of Canada and northern Europe.
The Atlantic wolffish has a distinctive appearance, with a long, eel-like body and a large head. It can grow up to 1.5 meters in length and weigh up to 40 kilograms. The coloration of the Atlantic wolffish varies, but it is typically dark brown or gray with lighter spots or blotches.
In terms of habitat, the Atlantic wolffish is primarily found in rocky areas, including kelp forests and deep-water reefs. It prefers cold water temperatures and is often found at depths ranging from 10 to 200 meters.
The Atlantic wolffish is a carnivorous predator, feeding on a variety of prey including crustaceans, mollusks, and other fish. It has strong jaws and sharp teeth that allow it to crush and consume its prey.
In terms of commercial value, the Atlantic wolffish has been historically targeted by commercial fisheries for its meat, which is considered a delicacy in some regions. However, due to overfishing and habitat degradation, populations of the Atlantic wolffish have declined in many areas. As a result, it is now protected in some regions and fishing restrictions have been implemented to ensure its conservation.

It has a compressed body and a dark brown or black coloration, which helps it blend into its deep-sea habitat. Fangtooths are relatively small, with adults typically reaching lengths of about 15 to 18 centimeters.

Due to its deep-sea habitat and relatively small size, the fangtooth has limited commercial importance in fisheries. It is not targeted specifically but may be caught incidentally in deep-sea trawls or other fishing gear. There is no significant utilization of fangtooth in commercial products or industries.
The fangtooth’s distribution extends to the deep sea and high seas, which are areas beyond national jurisdiction. These areas are often referred to as the “Area Beyond National Jurisdiction” (ABNJ) or “High Seas.” The fangtooth is adapted to the extreme conditions of the deep sea, including low temperatures, high pressure, and limited food availability.

Argyropelecus aculeatus, commonly known as the hatchetfish, is a species of deep-sea fish that belongs to the family Sternoptychidae. It is found in oceans worldwide, particularly in deep waters ranging from 200 to 1,000 meters below the surface. The hatchetfish has a unique body shape, resembling a hatchet or an elongated triangle, with a flattened belly and a slender, vertically compressed body.
Hatchetfish are small in size, typically measuring around 5 to 8 centimeters in length. They have large, upward-facing eyes that allow them to detect prey and predators in the dimly lit deep-sea environment. Hatchetfish are known for their bioluminescent properties, with light-producing organs called photophores located along their body. These photophores help them camouflage and communicate with other individuals.
In terms of ecology, hatchetfish are primarily mesopelagic or bathypelagic, inhabiting the twilight zone of the ocean. They feed on a variety of small organisms, including zooplankton, copepods, and other small fish. Hatchetfish have a unique feeding strategy where they swim near the surface at night to feed on prey that migrates vertically in the water column.
While hatchetfish are fascinating deep-sea creatures, they do not have any significant commercial use. They are primarily studied for their ecological roles and adaptations to the deep-sea environment. Hatchetfish are not targeted for commercial fishing or utilized for any specific commercial products.

title: 77  Asteroidea
text:
77.3 Summary:
Asteroidea, commonly known as starfish or sea stars, is a class of marine invertebrates belonging to the phylum Echinodermata. They are characterized by their radial symmetry, typically having five arms that radiate from a central disc-shaped body. However, some species can have more or fewer arms.
Starfish are found in oceans worldwide, inhabiting a variety of marine habitats, including rocky shores, coral reefs, seagrass beds, and sandy bottoms. They are known for their diverse colors and patterns, ranging from vibrant hues to more subdued tones.
Starfish have a unique water vascular system that helps them move and capture prey. They use tube feet, which are small, suction cup-like structures, to grip surfaces and move along the ocean floor. Some species can also use their tube feet to pry open shells of bivalves and feed on the soft tissues inside.
Starfish are opportunistic predators and scavengers, feeding on a wide range of prey, including mollusks, crustaceans, and other small invertebrates. They have a specialized stomach that can be everted to engulf and digest their prey outside their body.
In terms of commercial products, starfish are sometimes collected for the aquarium trade, as they are considered fascinating and visually appealing marine organisms. However, it is important to note that the collection and trade of certain starfish species may be regulated to protect their populations and the marine ecosystems they inhabit.

title: 79  Astronesthes

Astronesthes, commonly known as lanternfish, is a genus of deep-sea fish belonging to the family Stomiidae. It includes several species of small, bioluminescent fish that inhabit the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones of the ocean. Lanternfish are widely distributed in both tropical and temperate waters, and they are considered one of the most abundant and diverse groups of deep-sea fish.
Lanternfish have a distinct appearance with elongated bodies, large eyes, and rows of photophores (light-producing organs) along their sides. These photophores emit light, which is used for various purposes such as communication, camouflage, and attracting prey. The bioluminescent properties of lanternfish make them an important component of the deep-sea ecosystem.
Lanternfish are known for their vertical migration behavior, where they move up to shallower depths at night to feed on plankton and other small organisms, and then descend to deeper waters during the day to avoid predators. This migration pattern plays a crucial role in the transfer of energy and nutrients between different layers of the ocean.
While lanternfish are not commercially targeted as a specific species, they are an important part of the marine food web. They serve as a significant food source for various predators, including larger fish, marine mammals, and seabirds. Additionally, some species of lanternfish are caught as bycatch in commercial fisheries targeting other species.

title: 86  Balistes capriscus
text:
86.3 Summary:
Balistes capriscus, commonly known as the grey triggerfish, is a species of fish belonging to the family Balistidae. It is a demersal marine fish found in the western Atlantic Ocean, ranging from Nova Scotia to Argentina, including the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean Sea.
The grey triggerfish has a distinct appearance with a compressed body, a large head, and a small mouth. It is characterized by its grey coloration, often with darker markings and a yellowish underside. This species can grow up to 60 centimeters in length.
Grey triggerfish are typically found in rocky or coral reef habitats, often near structures such as wrecks or artificial reefs. They are known to be territorial and can be found in both shallow and deeper waters, ranging from 10 to 100 meters in depth.
In terms of diet, grey triggerfish are opportunistic feeders, consuming a variety of prey including crustaceans, mollusks, and small fish. They have strong jaws and teeth that allow them to crush hard-shelled prey.
Grey triggerfish are occasionally targeted by recreational and commercial fishermen. They are valued for their meat, which is considered to be of good quality. However, due to their slow growth rate and vulnerability to overfishing, there are regulations in place to manage their harvest and protect their populations.

Food: The meat of grey triggerfish is consumed as food. It is known for its good quality and is used in various culinary preparations.

title: 87  Bassia bassensis
text:
87.3 Commercial Products: TRUE
Bassia bassensis, commonly known as the Antarctic toothfish, is a species of fish belonging to the family Nototheniidae. It is found in the Southern Ocean, particularly in the waters surrounding Antarctica.
The Antarctic toothfish is a large predatory fish that inhabits the cold, deep waters of the Southern Ocean. It has a streamlined body, large mouth, and sharp teeth, which it uses to feed on a variety of prey, including fish, squid, and krill.
The Antarctic toothfish is commercially significant and is harvested for its flesh, which is highly valued in the seafood market. It is often marketed under the name “Chilean sea bass” or “white cod.” The flesh of the Antarctic toothfish is known for its delicate flavor and high oil content, making it a sought-after ingredient in gourmet cuisine.
Due to concerns about overfishing and the vulnerability of the species, the harvesting of Antarctic toothfish is strictly regulated. The fishery is managed through quotas and strict monitoring to ensure sustainable fishing practices and protect the population of this species.
In addition to its commercial value as a food product, the Antarctic toothfish is also of interest to scientific researchers. It serves as a model species for studying the physiological adaptations of fish to cold environments and has been the subject of various scientific studies.

title: 90  Bathycalanus
text:
90.4 Summary:
Bathycalanus is a genus of marine copepods belonging to the family Calanidae. Copepods are small crustaceans that are an essential part of the marine food web, serving as a primary food source for many marine organisms. Bathycalanus species are primarily found in deep-sea environments, particularly in the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones.
These copepods have a streamlined body shape and possess various adaptations that allow them to survive in the deep-sea environment, such as bioluminescent organs and specialized appendages for filter-feeding. They play a crucial role in the transfer of energy and nutrients from lower trophic levels to higher trophic levels in the deep-sea ecosystem.
While Bathycalanus copepods have ecological importance, there is no specific information available regarding their commercial utilization or exploitation. They are primarily studied for scientific purposes, including understanding their distribution, abundance, and ecological interactions in the deep-sea environment.
The deep sea, where Bathycalanus copepods are found, is a vast and relatively unexplored environment with potential for the discovery of new species, genetic resources, and bioactive compounds. Research in this area contributes to our understanding of deep-sea ecosystems and their conservation.

Antarctic dragonfish are small in size, typically measuring around 10-15 centimeters in length. They have elongated bodies and large heads with sharp teeth. These fish have bioluminescent organs called photophores, which they use to produce light for communication, attracting prey, and camouflage.

Bathylagus euryops is found in the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones of the world’s oceans, typically at depths ranging from 200 to 2,000 meters.
The deep-sea smelt has a slender and elongated body, with a silvery coloration that helps it blend into the dark depths of the ocean. It possesses large eyes, which are adapted to low-light conditions. Bathylagus euryops is a small fish, typically measuring around 10 to 15 centimeters in length.
As a deep-sea species, Bathylagus euryops is adapted to survive in extreme conditions, including cold temperatures and high pressures. It is a voracious predator, feeding on a variety of small organisms such as zooplankton, small crustaceans, and other small fish. It plays an important role in the deep-sea food web as both a predator and prey item for larger marine organisms.
In terms of commercial use, Bathylagus euryops is not commonly targeted or utilized for commercial purposes. title: 95  Bathyraja spinicauda
text:
95.3 Summary:
Bathyraja spinicauda, commonly known as the thorny skate, is a species of skate that belongs to the family Rajidae. It is found in the North Atlantic Ocean, particularly in the waters off the eastern coast of North America, from Labrador to North Carolina. The thorny skate inhabits deep-sea environments, typically found at depths ranging from 200 to 2,000 meters.
The thorny skate has a distinctive appearance with a rough, thorny skin and a flattened body shape. It can grow up to 1.5 meters in length, making it one of the larger skate species. The dorsal side of the skate is usually brown or gray in color, while the ventral side is lighter.
These skates are bottom-dwelling organisms, often found on soft sediments or rocky substrates. They are primarily carnivorous, feeding on a variety of benthic invertebrates such as crustaceans, mollusks, and small fish.
The thorny skate is not commercially targeted for its meat or other products. However, it is sometimes caught incidentally in commercial fishing operations targeting other species. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has listed the thorny skate as “vulnerable” due to overfishing and habitat degradation.

Beryx splendens, commonly known as the splendid alfonsino, is a species of deep-sea fish in the family Berycidae. It is widely distributed in the Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific Oceans, including the high seas and areas beyond national jurisdiction.
The splendid alfonsino has a distinctive appearance with a deep, compressed body and a large mouth. It can reach lengths of up to 40 centimeters. The body coloration varies from reddish-orange to pink, and it has a silvery sheen. This species has long, spiny dorsal and anal fins.
The habitat of Beryx splendens includes mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones, typically found at depths ranging from 200 to 1000 meters. It is a migratory species, moving vertically in the water column during different times of the day.
Beryx splendens is a predator, feeding on a variety of prey including fish, squid, and crustaceans. It plays a role in the deep-sea food web, contributing to the ecological balance of its habitat.
There is commercial interest in Beryx splendens, particularly in the Japanese market. The fish is highly valued for its firm, flavorful flesh and is often used in sashimi and sushi preparations. It is also processed into fillets and sold as a premium seafood product.

title: 104  Bolinichthys longipes

104.3 Summary:
Bolinichthys longipes, commonly known as the Popeye lampfish, is a species of deep-sea fish belonging to the family Myctophidae. It is found in the Indian Ocean (20°N-18°S) and the Pacific Ocean (30°N-20°S), including the South China Sea. The Popeye lampfish inhabits high-oceanic and mesopelagic zones, typically found at depths ranging from 525 to 725 meters during the day and 10 to 150 meters at night.
This species is oviparous, meaning it reproduces by laying planktonic eggs and producing larvae. The Popeye lampfish is a small fish, with a maximum recorded length of 5.0 cm. It has a slender body shape and lacks dorsal spines. The anal fin has 13-15 soft rays, and the vertebrae count ranges from 32 to 35.
The ecological role of Bolinichthys longipes in the marine ecosystem is not well-documented. As a deep-sea fish, it likely plays a role in the food web as a predator or prey for other organisms. Further research is needed to understand its specific ecological interactions and behaviors.

This species has a circumpolar distribution, occurring in the Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific sectors of the Southern Ocean.
The Supralateral lanternfish is a mesopelagic species, inhabiting depths ranging from 200 to 1,000 meters. It is a small fish, typically measuring around 10 to 15 centimeters in length. This species has a slender body with a silver-colored appearance.
Like other lanternfish species, Bolinichthys supralateralis exhibits vertical migration behavior, moving to shallower depths at night to feed on zooplankton and descending to deeper waters during the day to avoid predation. It is an important component of the Southern Ocean food web, serving as prey for larger predators such as seals, penguins, and whales.

title: 108  Brama orcini
text:
108.3 Summary:
Brama orcini, commonly known as the Bigtooth pomfret, is a species of fish in the family Bramidae. It is found in the Indo-Pacific region, particularly in tropical areas. The Bigtooth pomfret is a marine species that inhabits depths ranging from 1 to 1,229 meters. It is usually found near land masses.
The Bigtooth pomfret has a maximum length of about 42 centimeters, with males and females reaching similar sizes. It has a streamlined body and lacks dorsal spines. The species is characterized by its large teeth, which give it its common name.
In terms of ecology, the Bigtooth pomfret is a benthopelagic species, meaning it inhabits both the benthic (bottom) and pelagic (open water) zones. It feeds on a variety of prey, including small fishes and invertebrates. The species has a medium resilience and a low to moderate vulnerability to fishing.
While the Bigtooth pomfret has minor commercial importance in fisheries, specific details about its commercial utilization are limited. It is categorized under the high price category in terms of market value.
The Bigtooth pomfret is not specifically targeted in fishing and does not have significant commercial utilization or products associated with it.

title: 109  Bythocaris
text:
109.3 Summary:
Bythocaris is a genus of small shrimp-like crustaceans belonging to the family Hippolytidae. The genus includes several species, such as Bythocaris cosmetops, Bythocaris grimaldii, and Bythocaris propinquus. These species are commonly found in the deep-sea environments of the Atlantic Ocean, including the North Atlantic and the Mediterranean Sea.
Bythocaris species are benthic organisms, meaning they live on or near the ocean floor. They are typically found in depths ranging from 200 to 2000 meters, inhabiting soft sediments and muddy substrates. These shrimp-like crustaceans have a slender body shape and are adapted to their deep-sea habitat.
The ecological role of Bythocaris species in the marine ecosystem is not well-documented. As benthic organisms, they likely play a role in the food web as scavengers or predators of smaller organisms. Further research is needed to understand their specific ecological interactions and behaviors.

title: 110  Calanoides acutus
text:
110.3 Summary:
Calanoides acutus is a species of copepod that belongs to the family Calanoididae. It is found in the Southern Ocean, particularly in the Antarctic region. Calanoides acutus is a key component of the Antarctic marine ecosystem and plays a crucial role in the transfer of energy within the food web.
The species has a streamlined body shape and is characterized by its elongated antennae and large compound eyes. Calanoides acutus primarily feeds on phytoplankton and is known to undergo diel vertical migration, moving to deeper waters during the day and ascending to surface waters at night.
Calanoides acutus serves as an important prey species for various predators, including fish, seabirds, and marine mammals. It is particularly significant as a food source for Antarctic krill (Euphausia superba), which is a keystone species in the Southern Ocean.
While Calanoides acutus is ecologically important, there is no specific information available regarding commercial products derived from this species. The available literature focuses primarily on its ecological role, distribution, and population dynamics. Further research is needed to determine if there are any potential commercial applications or products associated with this species.

These copepods have a streamlined body shape and are well-adapted to life in the cold waters of the Southern Ocean. They feed on phytoplankton and other small organisms, serving as a vital food source for various marine animals, including fish, seabirds, and marine mammals.

Calanoides is a genus of copepods in the family Calanidae. Copepods are small crustaceans that are an important component of marine zooplankton. title: 113  Calanopia elliptica
text:
113.3 Summary:
Calanopia elliptica is a species of copepod that belongs to the family Pontellidae. It is found in the epipelagic and mesopelagic zones of the ocean, both in coastal and oceanic waters. The distribution of Calanopia elliptica includes the Indian and Pacific Oceans, as well as the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Georgia, USA.
The female Calanopia elliptica has a prosome (front part of the body) that is nearly twice as long as the urosome (posterior part of the body). The prosome has long points, and the urosome somite 2 is as long as the genital somite. The caudal rami (tail-like appendages) are nearly three times as long as they are broad. The male Calanopia elliptica has a maxilliped with an apical part that is five-segmented. The P5 (fifth pair of swimming legs) of the male has a terminal segment of the left exopod with a pad of fine hairs, pointed at the distal end with three setae on the outer margin and a seta on the posterior side. The right exopodite segment 1 of the male has a flattened margin produced into three strong, blunt teeth, while the claw-like second segment has three small pointed teeth.
Calanopia elliptica is part of several plankton communities, but little is known about its ecology. Further research is needed to gather more information about its ecological role and behavior.

title: 114  Calanus finmarchicus
text:
114.3 Summary:
Calanus finmarchicus is a species of copepod and a component of the zooplankton found in enormous amounts in the northern Atlantic Ocean. It belongs to the order Calanoida and the family Calanidae. C. finmarchicus is one of the most commonly found species of zooplankton in the subarctic waters of the North Atlantic.
This copepod species has a complex life cycle, starting from eggs that are shed into near-surface waters in early spring. The eggs hatch into nauplii larvae, which go through six consecutive moulting stages, resulting in progressively larger and more complex larvae.
C. finmarchicus is especially important ecologically as it shows rapid responses to climate variability, including shifts in species’ distribution and abundance, timing of life history events, and trophic relationships. It primarily feeds on different forms of phytoplankton, including diatoms, dinoflagellates, ciliates, and other photosynthetic marine organisms.
While there is no specific commercial product associated with Calanus finmarchicus, it is worth mentioning that Calanus oil (COil) is a natural product extracted from marine zooplankton, including Calanus finmarchicus, found in the North Atlantic Ocean. Calanus oil has been studied for its potential health benefits, including its use in the treatment of obesity-related low-grade inflammation.

title: 115  Calanus glacialis
text:
115.3 Summary:
Calanus glacialis, commonly known as Arctic copepod, is a species of copepod found in the northwestern Atlantic Ocean, adjoining waters, and the northwestern Pacific and its nearby waters. It has a wide depth range, from sea level to 1,800 meters. Females of Calanus glacialis generally range from about 3.6 to 5.5 millimeters in length, while males range from about 3.9 to 5.4 millimeters.
In terms of ecology, Calanus glacialis has a one to three-year lifecycle, consisting of six nauplii and copepodite stages. Reproduction occurs during the spring, with clutches typically containing 40 to 80 eggs. The development of eggs to stage I copepodites takes about 46 days during the summer when temperatures are below 0°C. The other stages are mainly completed during the summer. In the autumn, Calanus glacialis accumulates lipids before entering diapause, usually as a stage IV or V copepodite. During mid-winter, stage V copepodites develop into females. The species can follow different breeding strategies depending on the availability of ice algae blooms and resources.
Calanus glacialis is a filter-feeder, mainly feeding on microalgae during the spring bloom.
Limited information is available regarding the commercial value of Calanus glacialis, and further research may be needed to explore any potential commercial applications or economic significance of this copepod species.

title: 116  Calanus helgolandicus
text:
116.3 Summary:
Calanus helgolandicus is a species of copepod found in the Atlantic Ocean, ranging from the North Sea to the western coast of Africa. It is a planktonic herbivore and plays an important role in marine ecosystems. The female Calanus helgolandicus has an average size of about 2.9 millimeters, while the male has an average size of about 2.7 millimeters.
Calanus helgolandicus is widely distributed in the Atlantic, including the North Sea, and can also be found in the Mediterranean and Black Sea. Its range is expanding northward due to increasing temperatures caused by climate change. It is typically found in waters with temperatures between 9 and 20°C, with the highest abundance occurring between 13 and 17°C.
As a copepod, Calanus helgolandicus has a complex life cycle and reproduction process. It overwinters as a stage V copepodite, with only those individuals having enough energy stores being able to overwinter. The copepodites molt into adult females during the overwintering process, and the females breed in the following spring. They can lay their first few eggs from accumulated energy stores in the absence of food. Calanus helgolandicus has a maximum of about three generations per year, and its abundance is highest during spring and autumn in the central North Sea.
Calanus helgolandicus is a planktonic herbivore, primarily feeding on phytoplankton. However, it has also been shown to eat dead diatoms and feces from other members of its species. The copepod selects particles based on their structure, accepting dead diatoms and objects such as polystyrene beads as food. Faecal pellets are generally not accepted in whole, but when fragmented, they can be ingested along with alternate food sources.
While Calanus helgolandicus has ecological significance as an important component of marine food webs, there is limited information available on specific commercial products associated with this species.

title: 117  Calanus hyperboreus
text:
117.3 Summary:
Calanus hyperboreus, also known as Arctic copepod, is a species of copepod found in the Arctic and northern Atlantic oceans. It belongs to the subclass Copepoda, order Calanoida, and family Calanidae. Calanus hyperboreus is an important component of marine ecosystems, playing a significant role in the food web.
The size of Calanus hyperboreus varies depending on its location. Individuals in more temperate waters range from just over 4 to 5.5 millimeters, while those in colder areas range from 6 to 7 millimeters. The copepod has a clear body, generally colorless, with orange to dark red gut walls and posterior. It has a prominent lipid sac that is usually red-orange.
Calanus hyperboreus is found in the Arctic region, north of the Bering Strait in the Pacific and the Lofoten Islands in the Atlantic. It can occur at depths of up to 5,000 meters.
As for its ecology, Calanus hyperboreus is a herbivore and filter feeder, primarily feeding on phytoplankton and protists, especially diatoms. It reproduces between October and March, using lipid reserves to fuel reproduction. The females lay clutches of eggs at depths between 200 and 500 meters, usually at intervals of 9 to 10 days.
While there is limited information on commercial products associated with Calanus hyperboreus, research has primarily focused on its ecological role and life cycle. The copepod’s lipid content and energy storage have been studied in relation to its adaptation to the Arctic environment.

title: 119  Calanus pacificus

119.3 Summary:
Calanus pacificus is a species of copepod found in the Pacific Ocean. The female has an average length of about 3.1 millimeters, while the male has an average length of about 2.9 millimeters. It belongs to the class Copepoda and the family Calanidae. Calanus pacificus is distributed in the Pacific Ocean, from Alaska to Central America in coastal North America, and from Russia to Southeast Asia in Asia.
In terms of ecology, Calanus pacificus is a particle feeder, consuming plankton, copepod nauplii, and marine snow. It feeds on the food of greatest abundance and size, while also rejecting low-quality food and inert particles. The copepod has a complex life cycle with three generations per year and exhibits diel vertical migration behavior. It plays a significant role in the marine food web as a prey item for various organisms.

title: 120  Calanus propinquus
text:
120.3 Summary:
Calanus propinquus is a species of copepod, a type of small crustacean, belonging to the family Calanidae. Copepods are an important component of marine zooplankton and play a crucial role in marine food webs.
Calanus propinquus is found in the North Atlantic Ocean, particularly in the Arctic and subarctic regions. It is a cold-water species that is adapted to survive in low temperatures. This copepod species is known for its vertical migration behavior, where it moves between surface waters during the night and deeper waters during the day.
In terms of commercial value, Calanus propinquus has gained attention due to its high content of omega-3 fatty acids, particularly eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA). These fatty acids are beneficial for human health and have potential applications in the nutraceutical and pharmaceutical industries. However, commercial exploitation of Calanus propinquus is still limited, and more research is needed to fully understand its commercial potential.

These products are marketed for their potential health benefits and as key ingredients in the production of salmon, marine fish, and shrimp.

title: 126  Calocalanus plumulosus

126.3 Summary:
Calocalanus plumulosus is a species of copepod, specifically belonging to the family Euchaetidae. Copepods are small crustaceans that are abundant in marine environments and play important roles in marine food webs. Calocalanus plumulosus is found in marine habitats worldwide.

title: 142  Carcharhinus albimarginatus
text:
142.3 Summary:
Carcharhinus albimarginatus, commonly known as the silvertip shark, is a species of requiem shark found in tropical and subtropical waters of the Indian and Pacific Oceans. It belongs to the family Carcharhinidae and the order Carcharhiniformes.
The silvertip shark is named for the distinctive white tips on its dorsal and caudal fins. It has a robust body and can reach lengths of up to 3.3 meters (11 feet). Silvertip sharks are known for their striking appearance and are highly valued by divers and underwater photographers.
These sharks are typically found in offshore areas, including coral reefs, drop-offs, and seamounts. They are known to be solitary or form small groups. Silvertip sharks are opportunistic predators, feeding on a variety of prey including fish, squid, and crustaceans.
Silvertip sharks are not considered a commercial species and are primarily encountered in the wild. However, they are sometimes caught as bycatch in commercial fisheries targeting other species. Silvertip sharks are also protected in many areas due to their vulnerability to overfishing and their importance in maintaining healthy marine ecosystems.

title: 143  Carcharhinus falciformis
text:
143.3 Summary:
Carcharhinus falciformis, commonly known as the silky shark, is a species of requiem shark found in tropical and warm temperate waters worldwide. Silky sharks are large, slim sharks with a moderately long, flat, and rounded snout, large eyes, and small jaws. They have oblique-cusped teeth with serrations and a distinct sickle-like shape of pectoral fins.
Silky sharks are typically found near the edge of continental and insular shelves, deepwater reefs, and near insular slopes. They are often associated with schools of tuna and are known to be quick-moving and aggressive. Silky sharks feed mainly on fishes, squid, paper nautiluses, and pelagic crabs.
While silky sharks are highly commercial and targeted by fisheries, there is limited information available on specific commercial products derived from Carcharhinus falciformis. The flesh of silky sharks is utilized fresh and dried-salted for human consumption, their hide for leather, and their fins for shark-fin soup. However, it is important to note that silky sharks are listed as Vulnerable on the IUCN Red List due to overfishing and habitat degradation.

title: 144  Carcharhinus longimanus
text:
144.3 Summary:
Carcharhinus longimanus, commonly known as the oceanic whitetip shark, is a large predatory shark species belonging to the family Carcharhinidae. It is found in tropical and warm temperate waters of the world’s oceans. The oceanic whitetip shark is known for its distinctive long, rounded pectoral fins, which give it its common name.
Oceanic whitetip sharks have a robust body with a broad, rounded snout and large, circular eyes. They are typically gray or bronze in color, with a white or pale underside. These sharks can reach lengths of up to 4 meters (13 feet) and are known for their slow and deliberate swimming style.
Oceanic whitetip sharks are opportunistic predators, feeding on a variety of prey including fish, squid, turtles, and even seabirds. They are known for their scavenging behavior and are often attracted to areas with floating debris or the scent of potential food sources. These sharks are capable of covering long distances and are often found far from shore in open ocean habitats.
While oceanic whitetip sharks have historically been targeted for their fins, meat, and liver oil, their populations have declined significantly due to overfishing and bycatch in commercial fisheries. As a result, they are now listed as a vulnerable species by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). Conservation efforts are underway to protect and manage their populations.

title: 144  Carcharhinus longimanus
text:
144.5 Commercial Products Details:

Shark fins: The fins of oceanic whitetip sharks are highly valued in the shark fin trade. They are used primarily in the production of shark fin soup, a delicacy in some Asian cultures.
Shark meat: The meat of oceanic whitetip sharks is consumed in some regions, although it is not as commonly consumed as other shark species.
Liver oil: The liver of oceanic whitetip sharks is rich in oil, which can be extracted and used for various purposes, including in the production of cosmetics and dietary supplements.

Please note that the commercial exploitation of oceanic whitetip sharks is highly regulated in many countries due to their vulnerable status. The trade and sale of their products may be subject to restrictions and regulations.

Centroselachus crepidater, commonly known as the Longnose velvet dogfish, is a species of deep-water shark belonging to the family Somniosidae. It is found in the Eastern Atlantic, ranging from Iceland and the Faroe Islands to Portugal, Senegal, Madeira, Gabon, and the Democratic Republic of the Congo. It is also found in the Indian Ocean around Aldabra and the Travancore coast of India, as well as in the Western Pacific around New South Wales, Australia, New Zealand, and northern Chile. The Longnose velvet dogfish inhabits depths ranging from 230 to 1500 meters. It has a black or blackish-brown coloration, a very long snout, lanceolate upper teeth, and bladelike lower teeth. This species feeds mainly on fish and cephalopods. It is ovoviviparous, with 4-8 young in a litter. The Longnose velvet dogfish is not commercially targeted for specific products, but its flesh is high in mercury and it is utilized as fishmeal and a source of squalene.

title: 157  Cephalopoda
text:
157.3 Summary:
Cephalopoda is a class of marine mollusks that includes some of the most intelligent and highly evolved invertebrates. They are characterized by their bilateral body symmetry, prominent head, and a set of arms or tentacles surrounding their mouth. Cephalopods have a well-developed nervous system and complex behaviors.
Cephalopods are found in all the world’s oceans, from shallow coastal waters to the deep sea. They have a wide range of sizes, from a few centimeters to several meters in length. Some well-known examples of cephalopods include squids, octopuses, and cuttlefish.
These marine creatures have a variety of adaptations that allow them to thrive in their environments. They have excellent vision and can change the color and pattern of their skin for camouflage or communication. Cephalopods are also known for their remarkable ability to jet-propel themselves through the water using a siphon and for their complex behaviors, including problem-solving and tool use.
In terms of commercial value, cephalopods are highly sought after in the seafood industry. They are consumed as food in many cultures around the world and are considered a delicacy in some regions. Squid, octopus, and cuttlefish are commonly used in various culinary preparations, including sushi, sashimi, and Mediterranean dishes.
Cephalopods also have potential applications in biotechnology and medical research. Their unique physiological features, such as their ability to regenerate limbs and their complex nervous systems, make them valuable subjects for scientific studies. They have been used in research on neurobiology, vision, and camouflage, among other areas.
Overall, cephalopods have both ecological and commercial significance. They play important roles in marine ecosystems and have economic value as a food source and in scientific research.

title: 157  Cephalopoda
text:
157.5 Commercial Products Details:

Cephalopod seafood: Squid, octopus, and cuttlefish are commercially harvested and consumed as seafood in many parts of the world. They are used in various culinary preparations, including sushi, sashimi, grilled dishes, and stews.
Cephalopod ink: Some cephalopods, such as squid and cuttlefish, produce ink as a defense mechanism. Cephalopod ink has been used in art, writing, and as a natural dye.
Cephalopod-derived compounds: Cephalopods produce various bioactive compounds that have potential pharmaceutical applications. These compounds have been studied for their antimicrobial, anticancer, and neuroprotective properties.
Cephalopod research models: Cephalopods, particularly octopuses, are used as research models in neuroscience, behavior, and cognition studies. Their complex nervous systems and behaviors make them valuable for understanding brain function and behavior.

Please note that specific prices for commercial cephalopod products may vary depending on factors such as location, species, and market demand.

title: 161  Cercozoa
text:
161.3 Summary:
Cercozoa is a phylum of diverse single-celled eukaryotes. They lack shared morphological characteristics at the microscopic level and are instead united by molecular phylogenies of rRNA and actin or polyubiquitin. Cercozoa were the first major eukaryotic group to be recognized mainly through molecular phylogenies. They have a cosmopolitan distribution and are found in various habitats, including soil, freshwater, and marine environments.
Cercozoa exhibit a wide range of ecological roles. Many species within this phylum are bacterivores, acting as natural predators of bacteria. They play an important role in nutrient cycling and energy transfer within ecosystems. Some cercozoans are also known to feed on other eukaryotes, such as fungi and algae. They are an integral part of soil food webs and contribute to the decomposition of organic matter.
Due to the diverse nature of Cercozoa, they have been studied extensively in terms of their taxonomy, diversity, ecology, and evolution. However, limited information is available regarding any potential commercial applications or products derived from Cercozoa.

title: 162  Chaenocephalus aceratus

162.3 Summary:
Chaenocephalus aceratus, commonly known as the Antarctic toothfish, is a species of fish belonging to the family Nototheniidae. It is a large, predatory fish that inhabits the cold waters of the Southern Ocean around Antarctica.
The Antarctic toothfish has a streamlined body with a large head and a mouth filled with sharp teeth, which it uses to feed on a variety of prey, including fish, squid, and krill. It is an important predator in the Antarctic marine ecosystem.
This species is found in the sub-Antarctic and Antarctic waters, primarily in the Southern Ocean. It is known to inhabit depths ranging from 200 to 2,000 meters, although it is most commonly found at depths between 400 and 1,000 meters.
The Antarctic toothfish is commercially valuable and is targeted by fisheries for its high-quality flesh, which is prized for its taste and texture. It is often marketed as “Chilean sea bass” or “white gold.” The fishery for Antarctic toothfish is managed by regional fisheries organizations, such as the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR), to ensure sustainable fishing practices and protect the species and its ecosystem.
Due to its slow growth rate and vulnerability to overfishing, the Antarctic toothfish fishery is strictly regulated to prevent depletion of the population. Catch limits, fishing seasons, and other conservation measures are implemented to maintain the sustainability of the fishery.

Chauliodus sloani, commonly known as Sloane’s viperfish, is a species of deep-sea fish belonging to the family Stomiidae. It is named after Sir Hans Sloane, an Irish physician and naturalist. Sloane’s viperfish is known for its unique and intimidating appearance, with long, needle-like teeth and a large mouth.
Sloane’s viperfish is found in deep ocean waters worldwide, typically at depths ranging from 200 to 1,000 meters. It is a mesopelagic species, meaning it inhabits the twilight zone of the ocean where some light penetrates but is significantly reduced.
This species has a slender body and can grow up to 30 centimeters in length. It has a dark coloration, which helps it blend in with its surroundings in the deep-sea environment. Sloane’s viperfish has a bioluminescent organ called a photophore, located on its belly, which it uses to attract prey.
As an apex predator, Sloane’s viperfish feeds on a variety of smaller fish and invertebrates. It has a unique feeding strategy, using its long, fang-like teeth to impale and capture its prey. It is capable of swallowing prey larger than its own body size due to its highly expandable stomach.
In terms of commercial value, Sloane’s viperfish is not targeted or commercially exploited due to its deep-sea habitat and limited accessibility. It is primarily of scientific interest for its unique adaptations to the deep-sea environment.

title: 167  Chauliodus
text:
167.3 Summary:
The viperfish, scientifically known as Chauliodus, is a genus of marine fish belonging to the family Stomiidae. Viperfish are mostly found in the mesopelagic zone of the ocean. They are characterized by their long, needle-like teeth and hinged lower jaws. The typical length of a viperfish is around 30 cm.
Viperfishes are known for their unique adaptations and behaviors. They have a large mouth with long fang-like teeth, which they use to capture and grip their prey. Viperfishes are skilled predators and feed on a variety of organisms, including lanternfish, algae, fish eggs, and small crustaceans.
These fish are found in marine waters across the world, inhabiting both temperate and tropical regions. They can be found at depths of up to 1,800 meters and are known to migrate to near-surface waters at night. Viperfishes have been observed in deep oceanic waters beyond national jurisdiction, including the high seas and areas beyond national jurisdiction (ABNJ).
Viperfishes exhibit bioluminescence, which is the production of light by living organisms. This adaptation helps them attract prey and communicate with other individuals in their habitat. They have photophores on their bellies arranged in a row, which emit a modest bioluminescent glow.
While viperfishes are not commercially targeted for specific products, their unique characteristics and adaptations make them subjects of scientific research. Studies on viperfishes have contributed to our understanding of deep-sea ecosystems, bioluminescence, and predator-prey interactions.

It has a slender body with elongated jaws and sharp teeth. The body is typically dark in color, ranging from brown to black, which helps it blend in with its surroundings.

The Antarctic dragonfish is a predator, feeding on a variety of prey including krill, other fish, and small invertebrates. It has specialized adaptations for hunting in the dark, including large eyes and bioluminescent organs called photophores, which help attract prey.

title: 171  Chionodraco myersi
text:
171.3 Summary:
Chionodraco myersi, commonly known as Myers’ icefish, is a species of fish that belongs to the family Channichthyidae. They are native to the Southern Ocean surrounding Antarctica.
Myers’ icefish are adapted to the extreme cold and icy conditions of the Antarctic environment. They have a unique characteristic of lacking hemoglobin, the protein responsible for oxygen transport in most vertebrates. This adaptation allows them to survive in oxygen-rich waters without the need for hemoglobin.
These fish have a slender and elongated body shape, with transparent skin that allows their blood vessels to be visible. They can reach lengths of up to 40 centimeters.
Chionodraco myersi is a benthic species, meaning they primarily inhabit the seafloor. They feed on a variety of prey, including krill, other small fish, and invertebrates.
In terms of commercial use, there is limited information available regarding any specific commercial products derived from Chionodraco myersi. These icefish are primarily studied for their unique physiological adaptations and their role in the Antarctic ecosystem.

title: 172  Chionodraco rastrospinosus
text:
172.3 Summary:
Chionodraco rastrospinosus, commonly known as the Ocellated icefish, is a species of fish belonging to the family Channichthyidae. It is found in the Southern Ocean, specifically ranging from the South Orkney Islands, South Shetland Islands to the Antarctic Peninsula. This species inhabits polar waters at depths ranging from 200 to 400 meters, although it can be found as deep as 1,000 meters.
The Ocellated icefish has a maximum length of about 52 centimeters, with males typically reaching around 30 centimeters. It has a unique appearance with a translucent body and distinct ocelli (eye-like markings) on its fins, which give it its common name. This adaptation allows the fish to blend in with its icy surroundings.
In terms of ecology, the Ocellated icefish is a benthopelagic species, meaning it inhabits both the benthic (bottom) and pelagic (open water) zones. It feeds mainly on fishes and krill. The species has a long larval pelagic phase.
While there is limited information on the commercial utilization of the Ocellated icefish, it is considered to have minor commercial importance in fisheries. However, specific details about its commercial value and utilization are not readily available.
The Ocellated icefish is found in the Southern Ocean, which includes areas beyond national jurisdiction, often referred to as the “Area Beyond National Jurisdiction” (ABNJ) or “High Seas.” These areas are subject to international regulations and management for the conservation and sustainable use of marine resources.

title: 173  Chionodraco
text:
173.3 Summary:
Chionodraco is a genus of fish in the family Channichthyidae, commonly known as icefish. The genus includes several recognized species, such as Chionodraco hamatus, Chionodraco myersi, Chionodraco rastrospinosus, Chionodraco wilsoni, and Chionodraco xanthodactylus.
Icefish are a group of fish that inhabit the cold waters of the Southern Ocean around Antarctica. They are known for their unique adaptations to the extreme cold environment. Icefish lack hemoglobin, the protein responsible for oxygen transport in the blood, which gives them a translucent appearance. This adaptation allows them to survive in oxygen-rich waters without the need for oxygen-carrying pigments.
Chionodraco species have antifreeze proteins in their blood, which prevent the formation of ice crystals and protect their cells from freezing. They also have specialized gills that allow them to extract oxygen directly from the water.
Icefish are bottom-dwelling fish that feed on a variety of prey, including krill, fish, and other small invertebrates. They play an important role in the Antarctic food web as both predators and prey.
The commercial use of Chionodraco species is limited. However, they are sometimes caught as bycatch in commercial fishing operations targeting other species in the Southern Ocean. Further research is needed to understand the potential commercial applications of icefish.

title: 174  Chionoecetes opilio
text:
174.3 Summary:
Chionoecetes opilio, commonly known as the snow crab, is a species of crab found in the northern Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. It is a commercially important species, particularly in Canada and the United States, where it is harvested for its meat.
Snow crabs have a round body with long, slender legs and a reddish-brown color. They inhabit cold waters, typically at depths ranging from 30 to 200 meters. Snow crabs are known for their ability to migrate long distances in search of food and suitable habitats.
The meat of Chionoecetes opilio is highly valued for its sweet and delicate flavor. It is commonly used in various seafood dishes, such as crab legs, crab cakes, and crab salads. Snow crab is also processed into canned crab meat and used as an ingredient in sushi and other seafood products.
The commercial fishing of Chionoecetes opilio is regulated to ensure sustainable harvesting practices. The snow crab fishery is managed through quotas and strict regulations to protect the population and maintain the long-term viability of the fishery.

Snow crab legs: Snow crab legs are a popular seafood product, known for their sweet and tender meat. They are typically sold in clusters and can be steamed, boiled, or grilled.
Crab meat: The meat of Chionoecetes opilio is processed and sold as crab meat. It is used in various culinary applications, including crab cakes, crab salads, and crab dips.
Canned crab meat: Snow crab meat is canned and sold as a convenient and long-lasting seafood product. It can be used in recipes or enjoyed on its own.
Sushi: Snow crab meat is a common ingredient in sushi rolls, adding a delicate and flavorful element to the dish.
Seafood products: Snow crab meat is used as an ingredient in various seafood products, such as seafood salads, seafood soups, and seafood pasta dishes.

Please note that prices for these commercial products may vary depending on the location and market conditions.

title: 182  Clausocalanus brevipes

182.3 Summary:
Clausocalanus brevipes is a species of copepod that belongs to the genus Clausocalanus. It is found in marine environments and is part of the order Calanoida. Clausocalanus brevipes is characterized by its small to medium size and has a bifurcated rostrum in females, while the rostrum is reduced to a knob in males. The species is known to have six copepodid stages.
Clausocalanus brevipes is commonly found in the Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC) and is associated with the Subantarctic Zone (SAZ). It plays a role in the marine food web as a prey item for various predators. The species is spawned from the ACC, and a significant portion of it decays in the SAZ.
While Clausocalanus brevipes is an important component of marine ecosystems, there is no specific information available regarding commercial products derived from this species.

183.4 Summary:
Clausocalanus farrani is a species of copepod belonging to the family Clausocalanidae. It is found in marine environments, particularly in the Indian Ocean and Pacific Ocean. Clausocalanus farrani does not have any commercial value or known commercial products derived from it.
Clausocalanus farrani is a small copepod, with females measuring approximately 0.87-1.22 mm in size and males measuring 0.65-0.99 mm. It is distinct from other Clausocalanus species in having a ventral protuberance of the genital somite anterior to the genital pores in females. The shape of the forehead and rostrum also differs from other species.
The distribution of Clausocalanus farrani is primarily in the Indian Ocean and Pacific Ocean. It is found in the Gulf of Aqaba and the Red Sea, as well as other subtropical, temperate, and subantarctic regions. The abundance of Clausocalanus farrani and other Clausocalanus species varies seasonally and is influenced by environmental factors such as temperature and food availability.
Clausocalanus farrani and other Clausocalanus copepods play a role in the marine food web as important components of the mesozooplankton. They contribute to the pelagic ecosystem and are influenced by factors such as endoparasitism and intersexuality. However, there is no information available regarding any commercial products derived from Clausocalanus farrani or its potential uses.
Overall, Clausocalanus farrani does not have any commercial value or direct applications beyond scientific research and ecological studies.

title: 184  Clausocalanus furcatus
text:
184.3 Summary:
Clausocalanus furcatus is a species of copepod belonging to the family Clausocalanidae. It is found in the epipelagic zone of the ocean, including inshore coastal, coastal, and oceanic waters. Clausocalanus furcatus has a circumglobal distribution, occurring in tropical and subtropical waters of the Pacific, Indian, and Atlantic Oceans.
Clausocalanus furcatus has distinguishing characteristics that include the shape of the forehead and rostrum, the form of the seminal receptacle, and the prosome-to-urosome ratio. The size of females ranges from 0.94 to 1.31 millimeters, while males range from 0.70 to 0.92 millimeters.
In terms of ecology, Clausocalanus furcatus is a herbivorous filter feeder. It feeds, reproduces, and develops at low phytoplankton concentrations, making it well-suited for open ocean environments. The development time from hatching to adulthood is approximately 13 to 21 days at 20°C. It is most abundant in Tasmania from February to July, with peak abundance occurring between March and May, coinciding with the extension of the East Australian Current.
Limited information is available regarding the commercial value of Clausocalanus furcatus. Further research may be needed to explore any potential commercial applications or economic significance of this copepod species.

title: 190  Clausocalanus paululus
text:
190.3 Summary:
Clausocalanus paululus is a species of copepod, specifically a calanoid copepod, belonging to the family Clausocalanidae. It was described by Farran in 1926. C. paululus is found in marine, brackish, and freshwater environments.
Clausocalanus paululus has a robust body, and the rostrum (a projection on the head) is slender and curved ventroposteriad (towards the ventral side). The terminal points of the fifth segment of the female are not divergent and may have spinules on the inner side. The abdomen of C. paululus is four-segmented, with the proportional lengths of the segments and caudal rami being 38:20:18:10.
There is limited information available on the specific ecological niche and distribution of Clausocalanus paululus. However, it is known to be a pelagic copepod and is likely an important component of the marine planktonic community. It may serve as a food source for various marine organisms.
In terms of commercial products, there is no specific information available on the direct commercial use of Clausocalanus paululus. Further research is needed to explore the potential commercial applications and economic value of this copepod species.

Clio pyramidata, commonly known as the sea butterfly, is a species of floating and swimming sea snail in the family Cliidae. Sea butterflies are pelagic marine gastropods that have a unique wing-like structure called parapodia, which they use for swimming.
Clio pyramidata is found in warm waters of the Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific Oceans. It has a wide distribution, including subtropical regions, European waters, the Mediterranean Sea, the Atlantic Ocean (including the Azores and Cape Verde), the Northwest Atlantic (Gulf of Maine), the Caribbean Sea, the Gulf of Mexico, and off New Zealand.
These sea butterflies are small in size, with a maximum recorded shell length of 21 mm. They are suspension feeders, primarily feeding on microplankton in the photic zone after dawn and in deeper waters during the day.
While there is limited information available on commercial products specifically related to Clio pyramidata, it is important to note that sea butterflies, in general, play a significant role in marine ecosystems as a food source for various organisms, including fish and whales.

Colossendeis australis, commonly known as the Antarctic sea spider, is a species of sea spider in the family Colossendeidae. The Antarctic sea spider has a unique appearance with a large body and long, slender legs. It can reach sizes of up to 25 centimeters in leg span, making it one of the largest sea spider species. Despite its name, the Antarctic sea spider is not a true spider but belongs to a separate group of arthropods known as pycnogonids.
This species is primarily found in the benthic (bottom) zone of the Antarctic marine environment, inhabiting depths ranging from shallow waters to over 1,000 meters. It is commonly found on the seafloor, particularly in areas with sponges and other benthic organisms.
The Antarctic sea spider is a predator, feeding on small invertebrates and detritus. It has a slow growth rate and low metabolic rate, which allows it to survive in the cold waters of Antarctica.
In terms of commercial utilization, there is limited information available on the Antarctic sea spider. It is not targeted in fisheries and does not have significant commercial importance or products associated with it.

Comatulida is a class of marine invertebrates belonging to the phylum Echinodermata. They are commonly known as feather stars. Feather stars have a flexible stalk or stem that attaches them to the substrate, such as rocks, coral reefs, or sandy bottoms. They can also detach and crawl using their arms. The arms are covered in small pinnules that help in capturing food particles from the water column. Feather stars primarily feed on plankton and other small organisms.
Comatulida species exhibit a wide range of colors and patterns, making them visually striking. They have a complex nervous system and can exhibit coordinated movements and responses to their environment. Some species are bioluminescent, producing light through chemical reactions.
Feather stars play important ecological roles in marine ecosystems. They provide habitat and shelter for other organisms, and their filter-feeding activities contribute to nutrient cycling and water quality. They are also preyed upon by various predators, including fish and crustaceans.
While feather stars have cultural and scientific value, there are no known commercial products specifically associated with Comatulida species. However, they may be collected for scientific research, aquarium trade, or as decorative items.

Coryphaenoides subserrulatus, commonly known as the longrayed whiptail or four-rayed rattail, is a species of fish in the genus Coryphaenoides. The longrayed whiptail has a slender body with elongated upper pectoral-fin and outer pelvic-fin rays, which are much longer than the head length. It is characterized by having two dorsal spines, 134 dorsal soft rays, no anal spines, and 140 anal soft rays. The species also has rudimentary barbels.

title: 219  Crinoidea

219.3 Summary:
Crinoidea, commonly known as sea lilies and feather stars, is a class of marine animals belonging to the phylum Echinodermata. They are characterized by their stalked or unstalked body forms, with many species having a crown-like arrangement of feathery arms. Crinoids have a long evolutionary history, with fossil records dating back over 500 million years.
Sea lilies and feather stars are found in oceans worldwide, from shallow coastal waters to deep-sea environments. They are most diverse in tropical and subtropical regions but can also be found in colder waters. Crinoids are benthic organisms, meaning they live on or near the seafloor, attaching themselves to substrates such as rocks, coral reefs, or soft sediments.
These organisms are suspension feeders, using their feathery arms to capture plankton and organic particles from the water column. They have a unique feeding mechanism where they extend their arms into the water to filter out food particles, which are then transported to their mouth located at the center of their body.
While sea lilies and feather stars have ecological importance in marine ecosystems, they are not commonly targeted for commercial purposes. However, some species of crinoids are collected for scientific research, aquarium trade, or as decorative items. In some cultures, crinoids may have traditional or cultural significance.

In terms of commercial products, sea urchins, including Ctenocidaris spinosa, are harvested for their roe, which is a delicacy in many cuisines. Cucumaria frondosa is primarily distributed in the subtidal zone, ranging from depths of 1 to 200 meters. It is commonly found in areas with rocky or gravelly substrates, as well as in seagrass beds and kelp forests.

It is harvested for its body wall, which contains bioactive compounds with potential pharmaceutical and nutraceutical applications. title: 238  Cyclopterus lumpus
text:
238.3 Summary:
Cyclopterus lumpus, commonly known as the Lumpfish, is a species of fish in the family Cyclopteridae. It is a marine fish found in the cold waters of the North Atlantic Ocean and the Arctic Ocean. The Lumpfish has a distinctive appearance, with a large, round body covered in bumpy, scaleless skin. It has a sucker-like disc on its ventral side, which it uses to attach itself to rocks and other surfaces.
The Lumpfish is typically found in shallow coastal waters, often near rocky areas and kelp forests. It is a benthic species, meaning it lives near or on the seabed. The diet of the Lumpfish consists mainly of small invertebrates, such as crustaceans and mollusks.
Lumpfish are commercially important in some regions. They are commonly used in the fishing industry for their roe, which is processed into caviar. The roe of the female Lumpfish is known for its bright orange color and is used as a substitute for more expensive caviar varieties. The meat of the Lumpfish is also consumed, although it is not as highly valued as the roe.
In addition to its commercial value, the Lumpfish is also used in aquaculture. It is often used as a cleaner fish in salmon farms, where it helps control parasites by feeding on them. The Lumpfish’s ability to attach itself to surfaces makes it an effective cleaner fish, as it can stay in one place and remove parasites from the salmon.

title: 247  Cyclothone
text:
247.3 Summary:
Cyclothone is a genus of small mesopelagic fish commonly known as cyclothone or bristlemouths. It belongs to the family Gonostomatidae within the order Stomiiformes. Cyclothone species are widely distributed in the world’s oceans, inhabiting both tropical and temperate waters. They are found at depths ranging from the surface down to about 1,000 meters, with some species capable of vertical migrations.
Cyclothone fish have a slender and elongated body, typically measuring around 2 to 10 centimeters in length. They have large eyes and a large mouth with sharp teeth. Cyclothone species are known for their bioluminescent properties, which they use for communication, camouflage, and attracting prey. They have specialized light-producing organs called photophores located on their bodies, which emit light in various patterns and colors.
These fish are primarily planktivorous, feeding on small zooplankton and other small organisms. They play an important role in the marine food web as both predator and prey. Cyclothone species are a significant prey item for larger predators such as whales, dolphins, and commercially important fish species.
In terms of commercial products, Cyclothone fish are not directly targeted for commercial fishing due to their small size. However, they are often caught incidentally in commercial fishing operations targeting other species. They are commonly used as bait for catching larger fish species, such as tuna and swordfish. Additionally, Cyclothone fish are sometimes processed into fishmeal and fish oil, which are used in various industries, including aquaculture, animal feed, and dietary supplements.
